params.text:
Welcome to the second week of the course.

 

Well done for coming back! Whether you practiced every day or just dipped your toes in, simply showing up again is a step toward building a mindful approach to life. This week, we’re exploring stress, something all of us experience at some point. You’ll learn how mindfulness can help you respond to stress rather than just react to it, how it affects the brain, and simple techniques you can use in the moment when things feel overwhelming.

 

Before you dive in, take a moment to reflect on last week’s home practice:

  • Did you notice any small changes from your mindfulness practice?
  • Was there a particular time when mindfulness felt useful—or challenging?

 

If you didn’t manage much home practice, that’s okay! Mindfulness is a skill that develops over time, and the key is consistency rather than perfection. This week, see if you can continue (or start fresh!) with small moments of mindfulness in your day.
Start by taking just a moment to breathe:

params.text: Having seen the impact of stress on the brain, have a look at the below research into how practicing mindfulness can produce positive changes in the brain.

The amygdala is a key part of the brain involved in processing stress, fear, and emotional responses. When we experience stress - whether from deadlines, exams, or personal challenges - the amygdala becomes more active, triggering the body's fight-or-flight response.

While this response is useful in life-threatening situations, chronic stress keeps the amygdala overactive, leading to anxiety, difficulty concentrating, and emotional reactivity. Researchers have been exploring whether mindfulness meditation can help regulate the amygdala’s activity, reducing stress at a neurological level.

panels.title: The Role of the Amygdala in Stress

params.text:
A study by Taren et al. (2015) examined whether mindfulness meditation could alter how the amygdala connects to other brain regions related to stress regulation.

🧠 What they did:

  • Researchers studied 35 unemployed adults experiencing high stress.
  • Participants were randomly assigned to either a 3-day intensive mindfulness meditation training or a 3-day relaxation training (without mindfulness).
  • Before and after the training, participants underwent brain scans to measure changes in resting-state functional connectivity (rsFC), essentially, how different parts of the brain communicate when at rest.

panels.title: The Study: Can Mindfulness Change the Brain’s Stress Response?

params.text:
Before the training:

  • Individuals with higher stress levels showed stronger connectivity between the amygdala and the subgenual anterior cingulate cortex (sgACC)—a region involved in processing emotions and regulating stress.
  • This stronger amygdala-sgACC connection was linked to higher emotional reactivity to stress.

 

After 3 days of mindfulness training:

  • Participants in the mindfulness group showed reduced connectivity between the amygdala and the sgACC.
  • This suggests that mindfulness helped weaken the brain’s habitual stress response, making participants less reactive to stress.
  • The relaxation group, which did not practice mindfulness, did not show these brain changes, highlighting that the effect was specific to mindfulness training.

panels.title: Key Findings: How Mindfulness Reduces Stress in the Brain

params.text:
• Mindfulness helps retrain the brain’s stress response. 

    By reducing the connection between the amygdala and stress-processing areas, mindfulness allows you to pause and respond to stress, rather than automatically reacting.

 

  • These changes happen quickly. 

    Even three days of mindfulness training led to measurable reductions in stress-related brain activity, showing that benefits can appear even with short-term practice.

 

  • Mindfulness strengthens resilience. 

    By helping regulate the amygdala, mindfulness improves your ability to stay focused, manage emotions, and feel more in control during stressful situations.

Read the research article for yourself: 

Taren, A. A., Gianaros, P. J., Greco, C. M., Lindsay, E. K., Fairgrieve, A., Brown, K. W., Rosen, R. K., Ferris, J. L., Julson, E., Marsland, A. L., Bursley, J. K., Ramsburg, J., & Creswell, J. D. (2015). Mindfulness meditation training alters stress-related amygdala resting state functional connectivity: a randomized controlled trial. Social Cognitive and Affective Neuroscience, 10(12), 1758–1768. https://doi.org/10.1093/scan/nsv066

params.text:
The Nine Attitudes of Mindfulness

Mindfulness isn’t just about paying attention, it’s also about how we pay attention. Jon Kabat-Zinn, a pioneer of mindfulness practice, describes nine key attitudes that help us bring awareness, curiosity, and kindness into our daily lives.

These attitudes aren’t rules or strict practices. Instead, they offer different ways of approaching our experiences, whether that’s dealing with stress, navigating uncertainty, or simply being more present in the moment.

The audio below introduces the nine attitudes of mindfulness. As you listen, notice if any of these attitudes resonate with you. Which ones feel natural? Which ones might be helpful to explore further?

params.text:
Mindfulness for stress: quick practices for busy moments

Mindfulness isn’t about stopping stress from happening. It’s about learning how to respond to it differently. This week, we are exploring two short, practical meditations designed to help you reset when things feel overwhelming. We've already tried out the 3-minute Breathing Space. 

Now, we're going to try the STOP meditation.

There’s no need to sit in a certain way or stay perfectly still. Just find a comfortable position and follow along. There is no right or wrong way to do this.  Your thoughts will wander. When they do, just acknowledge it and bring your attention back to the breath. When your thoughts wander and you notice this, you are practicing Mindfulness! Give it a try and see what you notice.

You can download the audio file of this meditation, to save to your device for home practice, or bookmark the meditation video on YouTube.

🛑 Explore the STOP practice. This meditation guides you through Stopping, Taking a breath, Observing, and Proceeding, helping you step out of automatic stress reactions and respond with more awareness.

params.text:
This week’s home practice: Mindfulness for stress & emotions

Mindfulness is about learning how to bring awareness into real-life moments, especially when stress or strong emotions arise. This week, your home practice will focus on short, in-the-moment mindfulness techniques that help you pause and reset.

No pressure, just curiosity. Try these out and see what works for you.

This week, practice either the 3-Minute Breathing Space or the STOP meditation at least once a day, especially when you feel stressed or overwhelmed.

  • 🛑 STOP Practice – A structured way to pause, check in, and reset.
  • 🌬 3-Minute Breathing Space – A quick mindfulness break to ground yourself.

You can do them with the audio guidance, or without if you want! You don’t need to do them perfectly, just notice what happens when you take a mindful pause in your day.

panels.title: ☀️ 1. Try a short Mindfulness practice each day

params.text:
Since last week, you’ve been practicing mindfulness in one daily activity (like eating, walking, or brushing your teeth). This week, choose a second activity to do mindfully. It could be:

🍽 Eating a snack or meal (noticing taste, texture, and smell).
🚶 Walking somewhere (feeling your feet on the ground, noticing your surroundings).
🖊 Writing a text or email (pausing to notice your thoughts before sending).

This isn’t about slowing everything down, just bringing awareness to moments that usually pass by unnoticed.

panels.title: 🌿 2. Bring Mindfulness into Something You Already Do

params.text:
This week, if you’d like, keep a Pleasant Events Daily Diary. This is a simple way to train your mind to notice small, positive moments that might otherwise go unnoticed​.

Each day, try to notice one pleasant experience as it happens and write a few words about:

✨ What was the pleasant experience?
✨ How did your body feel in that moment?
✨ What emotions or thoughts came up?

You might be surprised at what you start to notice! Click here for a downloadable template is provided if you’d like to use it.
That’s it! No need to do everything. Just explore, experiment, and see what feels helpful.
